answers.answer: That name is beautiful!  I dont know anything about what you tested positive for but please let us know the outcome.  I do know that blood thinners are safe when you are pregnant because I was on them for a couple weeks back in the beginning of my pregnancy for a strange heart problem that popped up.

You said that your daughter is 3, so I'm assuming you got pregnant with her approx. 4 years ago. I think your body can change quite a bit for 4 years. In 2003 I had a full blood work (due to other circumstances) and everything was normal. In 2006 I had 2 m/c-es in a row and in Sept of 2006 the blood tests revieled that I have AT3 deficiency (kind of BCD).I advise you to start threatment. 3 m/c-es is something a little unusal when everything is ok. I don't think it'll hurt to start something just in case.The name is beautiful. I never found out what I was having:(

I just wanted to wish you luck and that I will be praying for you.  I hope that this is the problem, because this way they can give you something for it, and your next pregnancy will be fine.  I mean of course I dont wish anybody sick but, if you found out the reason, and are able to correct it, it may bring you some peace and you'll have a non eventful pregnancy.  I hope this is the case.  Good luck!

Hi, I am so sorry about your loss. I recently been diagnosed with MTHFR also one gene which is a blood clotting disorder too and I have a son who will be 11 in January and I have had 6 miscarriages with the last one being on 10/26/06 and started baby aspirin and metformin(helps clotting)and progesterone. I am 6w today pregnant again without even getting my period after my last loss. Everything is looking good so far in my opinion, it won't hurt you to take the aspirin 81mg so I would do it. I to had chromosomes done and they were healthy and normal.Hope this helps so let's pray for each other.Christie

Maybe this will help you.Testing for the prothrombin 20210 mutation, also called factor II mutation, may have been offered by your doctor because you or someone in your family, has had (1) a blood clot in one of the deep veins of the body (also called deep vein thrombosis or DVT); (2) a blood clot that has traveled to the lung (called a pulmonary embolism or PE); (3) a blood clot in an unusual site (such as the mesenteric or cerebral sinus vein); (4) a heart attack or stroke at a young age; or (5) a history of recurrent pregnancy loss or stillbirth.Here's the site: http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/full/110/3/e15

This to:Recently, there has been the suggestion that the prothrombin mutation occurs more commonly among women with certain pregnancy complications. These complications may include stillbirth (pregnancy loss after week 20), second trimester pregnancy loss, placental abruption (where the placenta detaches from the uterus), and preeclampsia (elevated blood pressure that can lead to dangerous consequences). Some studies have also shown a relationship between a mother having the prothrombin mutation and delivering a baby of small size. At this time, it does seem that having the prothrombin mutation may increase the risk of these situations, but it is unclear how strong the association may be.

Thanks so much for the info and everyone with their thoughts and prayers.I did ask if this condition occured between my first pregnancy 3 years ago...she was 2 in Aug...conceive Dec 1st 2003...and the dr said 'no that it is on one of the two sets of genes' so I most likely was born with it and it's hereditary (sp?).I'm can guess that it came from my mothers side as she has had several small strokes over the past year...nothing permanent or damaging but still...makes me wonder now.....uggh..I don't know.  I don't think it could hurt to take the aspirin everyday but how much and when....my dr didn't want to discuss that until I knew I was pregnant...but that could be to late for the baby.  My first 2 m/c were natural and very very early....5-6 weeks or so....So I also have a presecription for progesterone suppliments...should I start taking both now just in case we conceived this month?  We didn't use protection....Could I have already harmed my baby?  Someone please help?  My dr didn't say we should do anything until HPT is positive but again I'd be afraid that's to late.

thank you for your help...i have a question and if it's to personal or hard to talk about please let me know..i understand.you said you have a 11yr old son...and 6 m/c...were the m/c in a row or scattered?  and did you know of your condition prior to any of the m/c?  i guess my concern is this...if you knew of the condition and were being treated is there still a possibility of a loss?  which of course i'm sure there is but would like to hear from someone who experienced it...thanks...again if you don't want to answer that is fine...Many blessings on you and your little one

I for got to add, I take 1 81mg baby aspirin. You have to stop taking the progesterone on day 30-31 of your cycle or it will prevent your ovulation that month. Supp. work better then taking them by mouth. I would ask your doctor, he knows best.

Prothombin (pt) tests help identify clotting disorders...or helps tell you how soon your blood will clot if you are not clotting. You could start taking the aspirin to thin your blood just to cover you there for the next one....god bless and i wish you the best of luck (and many prayers) for the next one. :)

I had my son without any problems almost 11 years ago, had 6 unexplained miscarriages in a row after having him. I have been tested for everything possible until I miscarried my last one on 10/26,I changed doctors. I gave blood and tested with having MTHFR. I decided to start taking the baby aspirin and metformin before getting pregnant with this one and by the time the lab results came back positive having it. I was already a couple of weeks pregnant and I still continue to take the 81mg aspirin, progesterone, and metformin. No I did not know of my condition until recently. I have nothing to lose by taking all of this medicine being all of my looses have been unexplained. I do believe that there is still a chance of having another miscarriage but I praying. Hope this helps.Christie

Thank you very much for your thoughts and advice.  I know I cannot be on the pill any more as I had cervical dysplasia and my drs do not want me on the pill again.  With that said and know that a set of my genes has this blood clotting disorder I will never again be on the pill.Thanks again for your words of wisdom.

I'm sorry but I dont know much about any of this.  But I would think that they would try and fix the problem before you get pregnant again.  I mean, wouldn't that make sense?  In order to avoid another heartbreak?  Is your Dr. just a regular ob/gyn or is she a specialist? I just wouldn't want you or anyone else to go through a mc again.
my dr did say if i get pregnant i will be sent to a high risk ob/gyn...thanks so much for your thoughts and prayers...i'll keep you updated.

Hi. I just wanted to let you know a little about what I've learned about prothombin.  It IS hereditary.  Because it is genetic our entire family went and had testing.  Turns out that my mom, myself and my sister were all negative, BUT my uncle's daughter (mom's brother) was positive.  This genetic blood disorder is very serious.  It complicates many things including birth control (the pill).  Had I tested positive for the prothombin the dr. was planning to take me off the pill immediately because of the danger of clotting.  I don't know what the effects are during pregnancy....sorry!!!  Hope this helps a little. ;)
when you conceived your other daughter were you eating alot of greens??  and fruits??  sometimes that helps and could make a difference.  I saw it on discovery health( sorry I'm a baby junkie)  LOL..
Thanks for the tip - i was a vegetarian of 9 years so yes lots of veggies and fruit....that's all I ate.Also nuts, beans etc....Guess I'm going veggie again.

i just had my 3rd miscarriage in a row, with still no kids! i'm 26, and they just found that i have a blood clotting disorder called thrombophilia.  all my pregnancies have started out normal, and we've even seen the heartbeat on one of them.  but then i always miscarried and had to have 2 D&C's.  they finally found something, which i'm happy about. they said that because of the clotting disorder, the clots were blocking oxygen and nutrition to the baby, causing the loss.  i have to start seeing a hematologist, but they said i could get pregnant again, i will just have to start having daily injections of an anticoagulant called heparin or lovenox and everything should be fine.  i guess this is something common in women who have had 3 or more miscarriages. hope this helps.

question: I had a whole panel of blood work done and everything was negative except prothombin? (sp) Dr set this was positive on one set of my genes.  And could be but not positive on why I had 3 m/c in a row this year.  I do have a healthy little girl that is why the dr is only assuming this is the problem...it doesn't necessarily mean it is but possibly.Anyone can help...I want to start something soon...Dr sais aspirin or blood thinner...Since she can't ever know for sure this is the problem...what do I do?  I do have a healthy daughter from my first pregnancy...no complications.Please any advice would be appreciated...Thanks.PS - on a side note for anyone who followed my case - my 3rd and last pregnancy ended with d&e.  fetus was genetically normal with all the right chromosomes...and it was a little girl.I wanted to know.  Helps me mourn her correctly....I named her Anabelle Grace - may seem silly to some but I needed to call her something instead of the baby
title: Blood clotting disorders and m/c?  I tested positive for prothombin?
